title-group.article-title: Studying the effects of lumped end mass on vibrations of a Timoshenko beam using a wave-based approach

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Michigan - Dearborn, Dearborn, MI, USA

author-notes.corresp: C Mei, Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Michigan - Dearborn, 4901 Evergreen Road, Dearborn, MI 48128, USA Email: cmei@umich.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Mast antenna structures and robot arms are often modeled as beams with lumped end masses. In this paper, bending vibrations in beams with lumped masses at boundaries are studied based on the advanced Timoshenko theory. An exact analytical solution is obtained using a wave vibration approach, in which vibrations are described as waves that propagate along a uniform waveguide (such as a beam element) and are reflected and/or transmitted at discontinuities (such as boundaries and lumped mass attachments). The reflection relation corresponding to a bending incident vibration wave at the end mass is derived, which is assembled with propagation and reflection relations at classical boundaries to obtain the modes of vibrations. The effects of lumped end mass on vibrations of a Timoshenko beam are studied in detail.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Bending vibrations of a beam with a lumped end mass are often studied using the classical Euler-Bernoulli beam model (Laura et al., 1974; To, 1982). As is well known, the Euler-Bernoulli beam model considers only the lateral inertia and the elastic forces caused by bending deflections, and the effects of rotary inertia and shear distortion are neglected. As a result, the theory is not valid for higher frequencies, typically when the transverse dimensions are not negligible with respect to the wavelength.

Abramovich and Hamburger (1991) studied the influence of rotary inertia and shear deformation on thenatural frequencies of a cantilever beam with end mass. Lee and Lin (1992) studied vibrations of non-uniform Timoshenko beams with end attachments. Timoshenko theory has been applied in analyzing bending vibrations of uniform beams with attachments using various approaches such as the standard separation of variables approach (Bruch and Mitchell, 1987; Salarieh and Ghorashi, 2006), Laplace multiplier formalism (Posiadala, 1997), and Laplace transform approach (Magrab, 2007).

In this paper, a wave vibration approach is applied in analyzing bending vibrations of a uniform beam/rodwith lumped end masses based on the advanced Timoshenko theory. Wave vibration approach is particularly useful when describing the behavior of one-dimensional components in a structure, when a finite number of waves with given directions of propagation exists. From a wave vibration standpoint, the motion of a structure is described in terms of waves that propagate through the uniform structural elements and are reflected and transmitted at structural discontinuities (Cremer et al., 1987; Doyle, 1989; Graff, 1975). The propagation relations are governed by the equations of motion. The reflections and transmissions at discontinuities are dependent upon the continuity and equilibrium conditions at the discontinuities. Assembling the wave propagation, reflection, and transmission relations provides a concise and systematic approach for vibration analysis. In addition to the consideration of the influence of rotary inertia and shear deformation in the beam element, the dimension and the rotary inertia of the end mass are also taken into account. The effects of mass, width, and cross-sectional dimension of the end mass to the vibration of the beam are studied in detail. Both natural frequencies and modeshapes are obtained with varying mass, width, and cross-sectional dimension of the end mass.

This paper is organized as follows. In section 2, the equations of motion are presented. In sections 3 and 4, the propagation and reflection relations of bending wave components are obtained. In section 5, wave approach is applied for free vibration analysis of a beam with a lumped end mass. The effects of lumped end mass on vibrations of Timoshenko beams are studied in detail in section 6. Conclusions are drawn in section 7.

sec.title: 2. Equations of motion and wave propagation
sec.p: In the absence of damping, the equations of motion of a Timoshenko beam are (Ginsberg, 2001): (1a) (1b) where x is the position along the beam axis, t the time, y(x, t) the transverse deflection of the center line of the beam, ψ(x, t) the slope due to bending, I the area moment of inertia of cross-section, A the cross-sectional area, E, G and ρ the Young's modulus, shear modulus and mass density respectively. f(x, t) is the externally applied force. It can be seen that equations (1a) and (1b) are coupled through the slope and the transverse deflection of the structure.
The shear force V(x, t) and bending moment M(x, t) at any section of the beam are related to the transverse deflection y(x, t) and the slope ψ(x, t) by (2) (3)

sec.title: 3. Free wave propagation
sec.p: Consider the free bending vibration problem when no external force is applied to the beam. Eliminating ψ(x, t) from equations (1a) and (1b), one obtains the differential equation of motion (4)
The same equation holds for ψ(x, t).

Assuming time harmonic motion and using separation of variables, the solution to equation (4) can be written in the form y(x, t) = y0e-ikxeiωt, where ω is the frequency and k the wavenumber. Substituting this into equation (4) gives a set of wavenumbers that are functions of the frequency ω as well as the properties of the structure (5) where coefficients (6) are related to the bending stiffness, shear stiffness and rotational effects respectively.
The ± sign outside the brackets indicates positive- and negative- going waves. There exists a wave-mode transition at a cut-off frequency ωc, which is given by (7)

Below the cut-off frequency ωc, there exists a pair of propagating bending waves and a pair of decaying bending waves in the beam, while above the cut-off frequency ωc, there are two pairs of propagating bending waves. In audio-frequency applications, the former case is overwhelmingly the most common.
With the time dependence eiωt suppressed, the solutions to equation (4) can be written as (8a) (8b) where the wavenumbers are (9a) (9b)
Clearly the wave amplitudes a of y(x) and a¯ of ψ(x) are related to each other. The relation can be found from equations (1) as (Doyle, 1989): (10)
From which one has (11)
Thus the relations between the coefficients of y(x) and those of ψ(x) are as follows: (12) where (13)

Consider two points A and B on a uniform beam a distance x apart. Waves propagate from one point to the other, with the propagation being determined by the appropriate wavenumber. Denoting the positive and negative going wave vectors at points A and B as a+ and a- and b+ and b- respectively, they are related by (14a) where (14b) is the propagation matrix for a distance x. And (14c)

sec.title: 4. Reflections at boundaries with lumped masses
sec.p: Waves incident upon a structural boundary are reflected. In this section, reflections of bending incident waves at boundaries with lumped masses are obtained.
At a boundary, the incident waves A+ give rise to reflected waves A- , which are related by (15)
The reflection matrix r can be determined by considering the corresponding equilibrium at the boundary.

Figure 1 shows the bending vibration related free body diagram (FBD) at the boundary with a lumped mass attachment. From which the equations of motion at the boundary are obtained as (16) where m is the mass of the lumped mass, which is modeled as a rigid body. Jm is the mass moment of inertia of the lumped end mass about an axis normal to x and y and passing its center of mass, ym=y+h2ψm, and ψm = ψ. Figure 1.
FBD at the boundary with lumped mass attachment.
Substituting equations (2), (3), and (8) into equation (16) gives the relation between the incident and reflected bending waves, which is written in matrix form as (17)
The reflection matrix of incident bending waves is then obtained from equations (15) and (17) as (18)
The reflection relations at classical boundaries can also be easily obtained, they are (19) for simply supported, clamped, and free boundary conditions respectively.

sec.title: 5. Wave vibration analysis
sec.p: With the propagation and reflection relations derived, free vibration analysis of beams/rods with lumped end masses can be obtained by assembling these relations.

Figure 2 shows a beam/rod structure with a clamped and a lumped mass attached boundary at ends A and B respectively. Now consider the free response of this clamped beam/rod with the end mass. Denoting the incident and reflected waves at boundaries A and B as a- , a+ b+ and b- respectively, the relationships between the different waves are given as: (20) where rA and rB are the reflection matrices at boundaries A and B respectively and f(L) is the propagation matrix between A and B that is L distance apart. Figure 2.
Free vibration analysis of a clamped beam with end mass.
Solving equations (20) gives (21) where I denotes the identity matrix. For non-trivial solution, it follows that (22)

Equation (22) is the characteristic equation from which the natural frequencies of the beam can be found. The assembling procedures described apply to various combinations of classical and non-classical boundaries, one simply needs to apply the reflection matrices at the corresponding boundaries. The modeshapes can be obtained from equation (22) by deleting any one raw of the coefficient matrix and solving all the other wave components in terms of any chosen wave component.

sec.title: 6. The effects of lumped end mass on vibrations of timoshenkobeams
sec.p: To study the effects of lumped end mass on vibrations of Timoshenko beams, a beam with circular cross-section is considered. The cross-section of the attached end mass is assumed to be of the same type as that of the beam, though it does not necessarily have to be so. The boundary conditions of the end without the mass attachment are assumed clamped, though it could be of any type, classical or non-classical.

The material properties of the example steel rod are as follows: Young’s modulus E = 210GN/m2, Poisson’s ratio υ = 0.3, shear modulus G=E2(1+υ), volume mass density ρ = 7850kg/m3. The radius of the cross-section of the rod is 0.05m and its length is 6.00m.
The effects of the mass, width, and cross-sectional dimension of the lumped end mass on the vibrations of the Timoshenko beam are studied. Details are as follows.

sec.title: 6.1. The effect of mass
sec.p: The mass of the lumped end mass is allowed to vary from 0 (which corresponds to the special situation of a cantilever beam without end mass) to 100 times the total mass of the beam. For convenience, ‘mass ratio’ is defined as the ratio of lumped end mass over total beam mass. The cross-sectional dimension of the lumped end mass is kept to two times that of the beam. The width of the lumped end mass h is assumed 0.05m.

It can be seen from Table 2 that the natural frequencies of the beam with or without end mass attachment differ significantly. For a beam with a lumped end mass, the natural frequencies of the beam decrease with increased end mass. The lower dozen frequencies are affected the most.

Figure 3 shows the effect of mass of the end attachment on modeshapes of the beam. It can be seen from the modeshapes of the first eight modes that the nodal points are shifted towards the mass attached end. The greater the tip mass, the more shift. Figure 3.
Modeshapes of the beam with varying mass ratio.

sec.title: 6.2. The effect of width
sec.p: The nominal width of the lumped end mass is kept at h0 = 0.05m. The width of the lumped end mass is allowed to vary from 0 to 5 times the corresponding nominal values. The mass ratio is set to 1, and the cross-sectional dimension of the lumped end mass is kept to two times that of the beam.

Figure 4 shows the effect of width of the end attachment on the modeshapes of the beam. It can be seen that the nodal points are slightly shifted towards the mass attached end, the greater the width, the more shift. Figure 4.
Modeshapes of the beam with varying end mass width ratio.

sec.title: 6.3. The effect of cross-sectional dimension
sec.p: The cross-sectional dimension of the lumped end mass varies up to 100 times that of the beam.The mass ratio is set to 1, and the width of the lumped end mass is set to 0.05m. For convenience, ‘cross-section ratio’ is defined as the ratio of the cross-section of the lumped end mass over that of the beam.

Figure 5 shows the effect of the cross-section of the end attachment on modeshapes of the beam. It can be seen that the nodal points are shifted towards the mass attached end. The greater the cross-section of the tip mass, the more shift. Figure 5.
Modeshapes of the beam with varying cross-section ratio.

sec.title: 7. Conclusions
sec.p: An exact wave-based analytical solution has been found for bending vibrations in Timoshenko beams with lumped masses at boundaries. The effects of lumped end mass on vibrations of Timoshenko beams are studied in detail. It was found that the lumped end mass in general causes the natural frequencies of the beam to decrease and the nodal points of the modeshapes to shift towards the mass attached end; the heavier the mass, the larger the dimension, the greater the effect.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The author gratefully acknowledges the support from the CMMI Division of the NSF through Grant #0825761.
